message: Happy my wife and daughter could be here for my swearing in (missing my son though)! I am honored to represent Georgia's Eighth Congressional District in the 115th Congress and remain committed to working hard for the people of Middle and South Georgia. Thought I'd share a few pictures from our day.
This week, 229 years ago, Georgia joined the Union. SHARE and LIKE this post if you love our great state!

BREAKING NEWS: House Republicans introduce Obamacare repeal and replace legislation.  Last Congress, I was honored to co-chair a task force that authored the American Health Care Reform Act (AHCRA). Today, we re-introduced the AHCRA which fully repeals and replaces Obamacare. I hope this legislation will serve as the baseline for discussions on how to repeal and replace Obamacare, bring about debate on how to lower health care costs, and allow for input from both sides of the aisle- something Obamacare did not do.

For a break in political news, thought you'd like to read this lighthearted (and hilarious) story from the Oconee County Georgia Sheriff's Office, just north of our district. Glad they saved the llama! Will post later today about legislation on the floor this week- stay tuned.

The House is hitting the ground running to hold the executive branch accountable for expensive rules and regulations. Tonight, the House passed the REINS Act- legislation that requires approval by the people's representatives for major, expensive rules and regulations coming out of the federal government. #REINSAct Read more here: http://bit.ly/2jgDViW
Attention Middle and South Georgia: Several counties in Georgia's Eighth Congressional District are under a State of Emergency.  Please stay off the roads and be safe this weekend!!
Thank you to our Eighth District law enforcement for keeping our communities safe! #SupportBlue #TaketheLEAD2017 #ThankACop #lawenforcementappreciationday

Happy National Pharmacists Day! In many areas like my hometown in rural South Georgia, the town pharmacy is often a fixture in the community, and our local, community pharmacists play a major role in rural healthcare delivery.  In areas where a doctor can be many miles away, local pharmacists deliver flu shots, give advice on over the counter drugs, and help with those late night drugstore runs for a sick child.  Many people see their pharmacists much more often than their doctor, and there is a very personal relationship between pharmacist, patient, and physician.   If you’re in a pharmacy today, thank your pharmacist for all they do! #NationalPharmacistsDay

This is the most important thing we must address when replacing Obamacare. Turn the sound on to hear what it is.    I have a couple of questions: How is it that Obamacare can mandate Americans purchase a product from an industry that is exempt from playing by the rules?    Why did President Obama and Democratic leaders leave the health insurance industry exempt from the antitrust laws of our country in their bill?    And what will our Republican leaders and President-elect Trump do about it?    I don’t know the answer to these questions, but I do know that I will stand up and fight for American citizens. Antitrust laws are designed to promote fair competition for the benefit and protection of consumers.  Leaving the health insurance industry exempt from the antitrust laws of our country is only good for the health insurance industry- not Americans. We have to stand up and do right by the people.  Applying the antitrust laws to the insurance industry makes the market more competitive, which in-turn drives down premium costs and increases choice. Makes sense to me.

Fighting for small businesses. I supported the passage of the Helping Angels Lead Our Startups Act this week which makes it easier for startups to connect with investors and showcase innovative ideas. #smallbiz

The one-size-fits-all approach to federal regulation is devastating to America's small businesses, their owners, and employees. I voted for the Regulatory Accountability Act last week which directly address the burden of regulations to create jobs and reverses their negative economic impact by streamlining the writing regulations to make rules clearly understandable to American small businesses.

Please join me today in remembering and honoring the life and legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. May we reflect on the peace and equality he so courageously championed in order to make a stronger, more just America. #MLKDay
Here's a pretty interesting read for this Inauguration Week on how quickly the White House is transformed between incoming and outgoing Presidents. Thought you'd enjoy!

My colleague, friend, and fellow Georgian Rep. Tom Price is in front of the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee for his confirmation hearing for HHS Secretary today.  Mr. Price is an excellent choice for Secretary of the US Department of Health and Human Services, and I am confident that Tom will put his years of experience to good use as he plays a leading role in our efforts replace Obamacare with reforms that focus on the patient, drive down the cost, and increase the accessibility of health care for all Americans. Here's where you can watch!
Capitol is ready for President-elect Trump's Inauguration tomorrow! Thought you'd like to see some pictures.

America’s will have a great Secretary of Agriculture in Sonny Perdue, and I am confident Sonny will be an excellent representative of our state in his service to our country’s agriculture communities. Agriculture is Georgia’s leading industry, so we’re glad to have someone who understands our state’s agricultural needs and act as a champion for the needs of our farmers, ranchers, and manufacturers in the U.S. Department of Agriculture.
Getting ready to head to the 58th Presidential Inauguration with my family! Exciting day for our country.

Today, we witnessed our democracy in action as Donald J. Trump was sworn in as our 45th President. This peaceful transition of power is an important moment for our country, and I have a tremendous amount of confidence in President Trump that he will lead our nation in the right direction. I look forward to working with the President to get our country back on track and to ensure the United States of America is once again a secure, safe, and prosperous nation for all Americans. Here are a few pictures of the ceremony from my seat.

I hope you are staying safe in Middle and South Georgia! If you are in need of assistance or have any questions, please call my Tifton District Office at (229) 396-5175. We will work with you to put you in contact with the correct authorities. There is good information on WALB News 10's site below, as well. My prayers are with those already affected by the storms coming through the Eighth District.

Thank you to all of those who have provided mutual aid. President Trump called Governor Deal and has pledged his support to our state. You can read more about that here: http://on.11alive.com/2khtqfG  Gov. Deal has declared a state of emergency for Atkinson, Berrien, Brooks, Colquitt, Cook, Lowndes, and Thomas counties. If you are in need of assistance in the aftermath of the storm, you can call my Tifton Office at (229) 396-5175, and we will help to put you in contact with the correct state authorities.

Affected by the recent storms? The resources you need can be found here: https://austinscott.house.gov/storm_assistance  Please call my Tifton Office at (229) 396-5175 if you have questions. UPDATE: The counties under a state of emergency have been expanded to include the following: Atkinson, Baker, Berrien, Brooks, Calhoun, Clay, Colquitt, Cook, Crisp, Dougherty, Lowndes, Mitchell, Thomas, Turner, Wilcox and Worth Counties. 9 of these counties are in the Eighth Congressional District.
These guys have been at it non-stop all over South Georgia. Thank you, Georgia Search and Rescue.

With a heavy heart, I spoke on the House Floor about the lives we've lost in the recent storms in South Georgia and to thank those who have selflessly offered help. It is particularly distressing as the Eighth Congressional District is my hometown, and its constituents, my neighbors. If you are in need of assistance, click here for resources and information: http://bit.ly/2jYIJZW

Flew home last night and have been touring Thomas, Brooks, Berrien, and Cook counties today to assess need and see where I can be of assistance. The destruction is devastating, breathtaking. Thought I'd share a few pictures. The warehouse you see is the Disaster Relief Distribution Center in Cook County- it was an old, unused warehouse until Sunday when people started dropping off donations here when churches ran out of room. Now, its organized, has about 200 volunteers a day, and is sending donations to other areas in need. This is what Georgians are like- coming together to help their neighbors in a crisis.

Yesterday showed me the strength of Mother Nature. But even more, it showed me the strength of America and our communities here in Georgia. On my way to Turner, Worth, and Wilcox counties today to assess the damage. Mitchell Power is working around the clock to get power restored to 4600 homes in Worth County.

Just finished assessing damage in Turner, Wilcox, and Worth counties. Thought I'd update you in case you missed the news. President Trump has approved Berrien, Cook, Turner, and Wilcox counties in Georgia's Eighth Congressional District, as well as Dougherty and Crisp Counties in my colleague Congressman Sanford Bishop's District, for individual assistance through FEMA. This is something that Governor Deal requested, while Congressman Bishop and I have been working with the White House to grant this relief as expeditiously as possible. We will continue to make sure those impacted by these storms get the assistance they need to recover.

I want to clarify a few things for those asking about assistance for Worth County (and for others who may have questions). The individual assistance awarded yesterday from the White House and FEMA is NOT final. The declaration is amendable. My office has inquired about the status of Worth and our other counties under the Governor's original declaration. Worth County’s damage assessment has not been completed, but it is in the process of being completed within the next few days- same goes for several of our other counties. As FEMA and the state jointly complete their assessment of each of the 16 counties requested by Governor Deal, FEMA will continually amend the declaration. Those still in need of assistance, in Worth County and other areas, rest assured. President Trump and his administration have been unbelievably quick to offer assistance for majority of counties requested by Governor Deal. Governor Deal’s request for Federal Assistance included many other provisions which have not been granted, and more importantly have not been denied. As the federal government evaluates more areas based on need, it is my hope President Trump will strongly consider Governor Deal's request for Individual Assistance in Worth and Brooks Counties, Public Assistance in the many of our affected counties like Thomas County, and Hazard Mitigation for the entire state.

Passing along some helpful information from FEMA. Federal disaster survivor assistance teams are working in storm – stricken neighborhoods helping Georgians recover from the January tornadoes. Additionally, housing inspectors contracted by FEMA are reviewing residential damages with survivors on-site. I will post more information and updates for additional counties as they come.

The House passed legislation to benefit Middle Georgia with a bipartisan vote of 396 to 8! Turn the sound on to hear what I have to say about the Ocmulgee Mounds National Historic Park Boundary Revision Act that I co-authored with my colleague, Congressman Sanford D. Bishop, Jr. Our legislation is a welcomed example of what can be achieved when a local community, state leaders, and Members of Congress, from both sides of the aisle, collaborate towards a worthy goal.

Thought I'd share some more Storm Assistance information. A few things to note: Disaster Recovery Centers are slated to open in Cook and Turner counties (so far). That info is provided/will be updated here: https://www.fema.gov/disaster/4297  Also, the picture below is helpful to discern whether your country falls under Individual or Public Assistance. These are just the counties that have already been awarded assistance- FEMA's assessments are ongoing and more can be added. Information on how to register for FEMA assistance can be found here: https://www.disasterassistance.gov/  One last thing! I will be working to provide as many updates as possible here on my facebook and in my enewsletter that comes out every Sunday. Be sure to sign up for my enewsletter here: https://austinscott.house.gov/contact/newsletter

It was reported that Iran, the largest state sponsor of terror, tested ballistic missiles earlier this week.  In response, the Trump Administration has made the decision to impose additional sanctions on Iran. I applaud this decision, as the United States must continue to show a strong, united stance against these types of threatening activities, which violates UN Security Council Resolution 2231 prohibiting ballistic missile tests, and terrorism.  This week, my colleagues and I on the House Armed Services Committee heard testimony from John McLaughlin about the national security threats and challenges our country faces. I believe his assessment is spot on- the U.S. and our partners must remain vigilant as we navigate new threats to our security that increased technology enables, such as cyber warfare or ballistic missile testing from actors like Iran and North Korea. You can read what Mr. McLaughlin has to say below.
Go Falcons! Will you be watching today? What is your prediction? #InBrotherhood #RiseUp #Falcons
G makes a guest appearance in Speaker Paul Ryan's video from swearing in day earlier this year. Just click play (we're right in the beginning)!
More bad weather and tornadoes are coming through South Georgia tonight- please stay safe. If you haven't already, I'd suggest downloading the FEMA app. Be safe!

The Marine Corps Logistics Base Albany was damaged by the recent storms in South Georgia. In advance of my visit to the base tomorrow, I asked General Walter, Assistant Commandant of the Marine Corps, when the base will be back up to operational status and why this base is so critical to the U.S. Marine Corps. Turn the sound on to hear his answers! House Armed Services Committee Republicans
Still want to know ways you can help after the recent storms? Here are a few ways how you can assist in the recovery efforts.

My friend and (now) former Congressman from Georgia, Dr. Tom Price, was confirmed by the Senate to serve as our Secretary of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services this week. Dr. Price will be an excellent Secretary of Health and Human Services.  I am confident that Tom will put his years of experience to good use as he plays a leading role in our efforts replace Obamacare with reforms that focus on the patient, drive down the cost, and increase the accessibility of health care for all Americans. I look forward to continuing our work together on behalf of Georgians in his new role.

Storm Assistance Update! Feel free to SHARE with a friend who you think would want to know this information. The counties from the Eighth Congressional District included in Individual Assistance (assistance for individuals and households) are the following: Berrien, Cook, Thomas, Turner, Wilcox, and Worth (Crisp and Dougherty Counties right outside our district are also included).  Constituents in these counties can apply for disaster assistance HERE: https://www.disasterassistance.gov/  The counties from the Eighth Congressional District included in Public Assistance (assistance for emergency work and repair or replacement of disaster-damaged facilities) are the following: Berrien, Brooks, Cook, Lowndes, Thomas, Turner, Wilcox, and Worth.   There are several Disaster Recovery Centers in the Eighth Congressional District.  These centers are located in Cook County, Thomas County, Turner County, and Worth County. You can find out more information on Disaster Recovery Centers by clicking HERE: https://www.fema.gov/disaster/4297  As always, please do not hesitate to call my Tifton District Office at (229) 396-5175 if you are in need to assistance, and a member of my staff will make every attempt to connect you with the correct

I visited Marine Corps Logistics Base Albany to see firsthand the damage done by the recent tornadoes in South Georgia. MCLB Albany can count on me to ensure they have what they need and to work across the aisle with my colleague Congressman Sanford Bishop to get the base back up and running.
Great video from Moody Air Force Base in advance of the Flying Tiger's 75th Anniversary. #FlyingTigers
Happy Valentine's Day to Georgia's Eighth Congressional District! I am thankful everyday for my Valentine, Vivien, who is a wonderful mother to our children and a supportive wife.

Enjoyed talking with WGXA this afternoon! We discussed important matters relating to Georgia’s Eighth Congressional District like repealing the Affordable Care Act and replacing it with patient-centered health care that is affordable for all Americans, as well as how improvements to our weather radar and technology have been critical during severe weather events like the tornadoes that recently hit South Georgia.

I testified in front of the House Judiciary Committee about one of the top issues in the health care industry that we must address when repealing and replacing the Affordable Care Act (ACA) – turn the sound on to hear what it is.  I want to be clear that I believe there were a number of problems in the health insurance market before the ACA passed. However, leaving the health insurance industry exempt from the antitrust laws of our country was one of the ACA’s most egregious missteps. This exemption is not only damaging to the consumer, leaving constituents in some counties I represent with only one choice of health insurer, but it also limits American's access to those who provide our health care like our physicians, hospitals, and pharmacies. I don’t think this issue alone solves all of the problems in the health care industry, but I don't think that any of the problems in the insurance market will be solved if this exemption stays in place.

What do taxes and weather radar have in common? Well... nothing. But hear what I have to say regarding our corporate tax rate and legislation to improve weather radar systems (to help in severe weather events, like the recent tornadoes in South Georgia) by clicking below!
Do you agree?
Happy Presidents' Day!

Great meeting with Brooks County Family Connection, Inc. in my Tifton Office this week. We had a great discussion about the work they are doing as the local decision-making body committed to improving conditions for at-risk children, families, and communities in Brooks County.

Spent some time this afternoon with Gray Television Washington News Bureau talking about on what’s going on in Washington right now. I enjoyed discussing what to expect tonight from President Trump’s speech and how we can continue working together to promote economic growth for American citizens.
President Trump makes his first Joint Address to Congress tonight. Will you be tuning in? What do you hope to hear? #JointAddress

Did you catch my interview with Scott James on TALK 92.1 this morning? In case you missed it, here’s a rundown of what we talked about.   As a member of Congress, and as a Georgian, I was glad to hear President Trump make it clear he is looking towards the future to unite Americans, rebuild the economy, and put Americans back to work- something that many of you in Middle and South Georgia have repeatedly said is your number one concern. I am especially encouraged by his commitment to rebuilding our military, supporting our warfighters, and keeping us safe. He has exemplified this commitment by his appointment of General Mattis as Secretary of Defense.   I was also glad to hear about the President’s commitment to working with Dr. Tom Price from Georgia as our Secretary of HHS and Congress to replace Obamacare with a system that expands choice, increases access, and lowers costs; a patient-centered, free market solution that does not exclude people for pre-existing conditions and gives states the flexibility and resources they need to ensure no one is slipping through the cracks. I believe we must focus on repealing the antitrust exemption for the health care industry, an effort on which I’ve been working very hard. Two weeks ago, I testified in front of the Judiciary Committee about a bill that would repeal this exemption- that bill just passed the Committee this week.   We have to give President Trump a chance- and if we do, I firmly believe he'll be a good President. Some of this will mean keeping the men and women of the administration in our prayers. I look forward to working with President Trump to create a more prosperous, safer America for future generations.  In addition to President Trump’s address, we also discussed the future of Moody Air Force Base. One thing other bases don't have is the ability to transition from one mission to the other like we do at Moody. Moody has the ability to take on new missions, like training pilots from our ally countries, making the base, and the warfighters stationed there, a vital asset to our national security.

I got a little... let's call it passionate... on the House Floor on Wednesday night.  But I had a good reason! Generic drug prices are skyrocketing, affecting families and patients who are forced to choose between medicine and their health or paying their mortgage and making ends meet. These astronomical prices put vulnerable patients in a difficult situation at a time where they least need to be thinking of dollars and cents.  I don’t think this is a decision Americans should have to make.   I mentioned my heart wrenching discussion with a mother from Warner Robins whose daughter has juvenile diabetes. She has to have insulin or she dies. This drug can be found in other countries for just a fraction of what they have to pay for it here in America, and they are struggling with the cost of the drug.   In my speech, I also talked about a parent who I met with last week.  His son is named Gabe, and Gabe suffers from Duchenne muscular Dystrophy, a rare genetic disorder that requires a drug called Deflazacort to stay alive. Gabe is now 11 years old and has been taking Deflazacort since he was 5. Gabe’s family currently pays roughly $418.83 per year for Deflazacort from Europe, as it has not been available in the United States. However, recently, Marathon Pharmaceuticals bought the rights to Deflazacort.  Note I say bought the rights, because they spent almost nothing on research, development or trials.  Then, they to bring the drug to market under the name Emflaza priced at $89,000 a year. 89 THOUSAND for the same drug Gabe's family was having to get from another country for under $419 a year. This is the drug an 11 year old boy is taking to live. The American system should be set up in such a way as to drive costs down and increase availability of life-saving drugs, not the other way around.    This Congress, I call on my colleagues to work with me to ease the regulatory burden the FDA places on generic drug applicants in order to increase competition in this market, which currently has little to no competitors to drive down costs. We must also alleviate the FDA’s backlog on generic drug applications to bring more drugs to market.   In the coming months, I look forward to finding a conservative, free market solution to address the problematic rise in generic drug prices for American families.

Glad I could visit with members from Georgia Farm Bureau Young Farmers today before heading to votes. Since Georgia is one of the top agricultural states in our country, it was great to see such an inspiring group of young agricultural leaders.

Congratulations to the Warner Robins Air Logistics Complex on being awarded the top depot maintenance unit in the U.S. Air Force for the second year in a row! Robins Air Force base is a strategic asset to the United States and its national security mission. It plays an important role in the global fight against terrorism, provides strategic depth, and command & control capability. It’s a privilege to represent Robins Air Force Base.  Take a look at the link below to learn more about this prestigious award given to Warner Robins Air Logistics Complex (WRALC).

Georgia’s agricultural roots run deep and contribute to a big slice of our state’s economy. Rest assured I’ll continue fighting for farmers in the Eighth District to ensure Washington works for and not against you. Happy National Ag Day to all our 8th District farmers.

Had a great meeting with Pentagon, Marine Corps, and Albany officials yesterday on the state of storm recovery at Marine Corps Logistics Base Albany and updating them on ways we’re fighting for funding to help.

If you are a resident of Berrien, Cook, Crisp, Dougherty, Thomas, Turner, Wilcox, or Worth counties and were affected by the January storms, tornadoes and flooding, today is the last day to register with FEMA for disaster assistance. You can do that online at www.DisasterAssistance.gov, or by calling 800-621-3362.

There’s a good healthy discussion going on and a unified message that we need to find a solution because a lot of Americans will continue to suffer under the burdens of increased costs, diminished access to care, and a lower quality of care that resulted from President Obama's health care law unless we repeal it.

The 2017 Congressional Art Competition is here, and it’s YOUR choice who wins the People’s Choice Award for Georgia’s Eighth Congressional District.  LIKE your favorite piece of artwork before Tuesday, April 4th at noon and the picture with the most “likes” will hang in my DC office lobby for one year.  All of these submissions are by talented high school students across the district.  Which piece is your favorite?
To all our Vietnam Veterans: Thank you for your bravery, courage, and service. Your sacrifices will never be forgotten.

Coming up in a few minutes here, I’ll be chairing a subcommittee hearing on credit programs and the next Farm Bill. You can watch the hearing live by clicking here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UMgXPxmzpm4.

The JSTARS fleet is vital to our airborne battle management, and most Americans would be surprised to know some of these critically important aircraft are nearly fifty years old. I'm committed to protecting and promoting the fleet’s recapitalization, and working on policies that meet the requirements our military needs to keep our homeland and men and women in uniform safe and prepared to take on any threats.

The Congressional Art Competition is a great way to showcase the talent of students across the Eighth District, and this year’s crop of submissions was certainly no exception. I would like to personally extend a ‘congratulations’ to this year’s winners, as well as to each and every submission I received this year, and extend a ‘thank you’ to the art teachers who inspire the talent, creativity, and confidence of these students. As I pass by these great works, either in our district offices or in the U.S. Capitol, I will be reminded that the work we’re doing today is to ensure a brighter future for them.
NA

I stopped by the new Georgia State Patrol Hangar in Perry this week. This project has been a long time coming, and it was great to see up close and personal the tools our law enforcement officials utilize in keeping Georgians safe.
He is Risen! Wishing you a Happy Easter from our family to yours.

Georgians certainly understand the importance our nation’s agriculture industry plays in our state and national economy and in keeping the world fed. Between his public service to the state of Georgia and his background in agribusiness, Sonny is the perfect choice to lead USDA. I am confident he will continue to be a champion for the needs of our farmers, ranchers, and manufacturers, and I congratulate him on his confirmation to be United States Secretary of Agriculture.

April is Lineman Appreciation Month in Georgia, a time to honor the men and women who keep our great nation powered. Following the destructive storms in January, the hard work and dedication of our linemen was on full display as they worked around the clock to get our communities back on the grid. Thanks to all our linemen and the important work you do in keeping America connected and running. #ThankaLineman
This week, I was honored to receive the “Friend of Farm Bureau” award from Farm Bureau and Georgia Farm Bureau for my work supporting farmers and ranchers.
Our thoughts are with the family and friends of 1st Lt. Weston C. Lee of Bluffton who was killed in Iraq over the weekend. We thank and honor him for his service to our nation.

Yesterday, NOAA Fisheries announced the federal red snapper season for recreational fishermen in the Gulf will run for only three days, while the commercial industry will continue to be allocated year-round access to the same federal red snapper fisheries in the Gulf. It’s a clear game of the federal government picking winners and losers, and its result is vast sums of wealth for just a select few at the expense of the recreational angler.

Today’s funding bill takes a big step forward in ensuring our men and women in uniform have the resources they need to tackle 21st century threats.   Some highlights include: --Provides $128 million to further the development of the next generation JSTARS intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance, and battle management aircraft, and $19.7 million for mission computer upgrades to two E-8C JSTARS aircraft currently flown out of Robins Air Force Base.  --Supports the fleet of A-10C Warthog aircraft flown out of Moody Air Force Base and prohibits retirement of the crucial close-air support asset and provides $20 million for wing replacements for the A-10C fleet.  --Includes critical maintenance and sustainment funding for the military, including for work performed on combat aircraft at the Robins Air Logistics Center and combat vehicles at Marine Corps Logistics Base in Albany.  --Provides a 2.1% pay raise for the more than 100,000 active duty service members stationed throughout Georgia.

Yesterday, I had the honor to present three young men from Houston County  with Congressional Certificates and congratulate them on their appointments to our prestigious US Service Academies. This is an extraordinary achievement that they have spent years working towards and for no greater calling than to serve our country.  It is the best of the best that actually get selected to go to an Academy. I congratulate them on their achievements and look forward to their continued success.

Had the opportunity to present another Eighth District graduating senior with a Congressional Certificate recognizing his appointment to one of our U.S. Service Military Academies. Jackson Danner of Lowndes County is headed to U.S. Military Academy, West Point. Congratulations, Jackson, and thank you for your service to our country.

It was great to meet with educators and parents at the Thomasville Community Resource Center yesterday. The center is a Federal 21st Century Community Learning Center (CCLC) and provides academic enrichment opportunities during non-school hours for children, particularly students, in the rural communities of Thomas and Grady Counties.  The program helps students meet state and local student standards in core academic subjects and offers other activities that complement their regular academic programs. One of the wins in last week's bipartisan passed spending bill was that 21st CCLC's received increased funding for their after school programs, giving more kids more opportunities for success.

This week is National Police Week, a time to recognize our law enforcement officials as well as remember those officers who’ve fallen in the line of duty. To our officers: Thank you for the tireless work you do in protecting our families, friends, neighbors, and communities.  This week is for you. #PoliceWeek

The Ag Committee held a hearing with USDA Secretary Sonny Perdue this morning. During the hearing, I had the chance to discuss with Secretary Perdue the importance of broadband infrastructure in rural communities. We also discussed the good work programs like 4-H and FFA do in engaging and supporting students. You can watch here:

I wanted to share a column by our former Governor Sonny Perdue on the importance of agriculture trade and the positive impact it makes on our economy. Farmers are lucky to have an advocate like Sonny leading the USDA and representing rural America.
An attack on democracy is an attack on all of us. Our thoughts and prayers are with the family and friends of those killed and injured in this senseless attack.

Exciting morning at Robins AFB as the RQ-4 Global Hawk was the first unmanned aircraft to land at the base! It's set for some maintenance. Very cool, and a big opportunity for Robins and the surrounding community.

Nationwide, May is Military Appreciation Month, a time to celebrate and honor those who’ve raised their hand and taken the oath to serve their fellow Americans. I took some time to write down my thanks, and I wanted to share them with you. To our service members: Thank you for the sacrifices you make to defend our great country. We celebrate you not only this month, but each and every day. EDIMGIAFAD.
Today we honor those brave men and women who've paid the ultimate sacrifice for our freedoms.

Late last week, Army Specialist Etienne J. Murphy of Loganville was killed in Syria. He was twenty-two years old. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family and friends during this time, and we thank him and honor him for his serve to our nation.

Members of the House Armed Services Committee and I are in East Asia for the next several days meeting with world leaders and discussing the impacts of continued security cooperation and support between the United States and our allies. Stay tuned for more updates from the road.

I spent Memorial Day honoring the fallen soldiers of the Korean War at the War Memorial of Korea in Seoul, South Korea.  It was a humbling experience and a time to reflect on the sacrifices our men and women in uniform make to defend our freedoms and the freedoms of democracy around the world.

Today is the last day of Military Appreciation Month, and this morning our Delegation had the opportunity to meet with U.S. Marines at the American Embassy in Hanoi, Vietnam and thank them for their service to our great nation. I ask you to join me in thanking our men and women in uniform not only today but each and every day. EDIMGIAFAD.

Last week, the U.S. Air Force performed an “Elephant Walk” and a “surge exercise” at Moody Air Force Base. Aircraft from the 23d Wing conducted the exercise operating A-10C Thunderbolt IIs, HH-60G Pave Hawks, and HC-130J Combat King II aircraft. It was a great display of U.S. aircraft combat power and defense capability in the skies.

Yesterday, I had the opportunity to tour the Hỏa Lò Prison—or “Hanoi Hilton”—in Hanoi, Vietnam where many U.S. warfighters were kept as POWs during the Vietnam War. It was a humbling experience and a time to reflect on those who’ve given so much for our country, especially those who never returned home. To our veterans: Thank you, and welcome home.

Good news out of Lowndes County as more folks in our rural communities now have access to broadband. Reliable broadband infrastructure is critical to growth in our rural communities, and I am committed to pushing for infrastructure investments that connect small town America through dependable, high-speed broadband service.

Great morning at Dobbins Air Reserve Base with Vice President Mike Pence and Georgia Delegation Members in supporting our troops and thanking them for their commitment and service to our great nation.
Praying for my colleague and friend House Majority Whip Steve Scalise and others shot this morning during a morning baseball practice in a D.C. suburb.
Thank you to the brave men and women who have answered the call to defend our great nation. Happy 242nd Birthday to the U.S. Army!

Today is the last day for two of our interns: Analhi of Americus and Matt of Johns Creek. These two young Georgians have been busy helping our legislative staff, giving constituent tours, attending briefings, and speaking with constituents who call our D.C. office. We wish them the best and thank them for their service to the people of the 8th District.

“Rural America is stranded in the dial-up age.” I couldn’t have said it better myself. Lack of broadband service means less growth and fewer opportunities in communities across the country. That’s why I’m pressing for updated and upgraded broadband framework in any infrastructure packages that come out of Congress. A strong and thriving rural America mean a strong and thriving USA. Read some of my thoughts:

Yesterday in my Tifton office, I met with several members of Indivisible Women of South Georgia. I am grateful for their personal stories shared as we had a productive dialogue about health care concerns and other issues impacting Georgia's Eighth District.

Today the President signed new VA accountability legislation into law, bringing full circle a years-long bipartisan effort to fix our broken VA to provide better care for those who've sacrificed so much for our great nation.

Affordable, reliable broadband access is critical to economic growth and a higher quality of life in rural communities around the country, and I applaud President Trump on his pledge to promote and foster critical broadband infrastructure investments in rural America.

In just a few minutes, we'll be getting back to the House Armed Services Committee mark up of the FY18 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA). We've just finished our second break of the day to vote, but we have many more hours of debate left to go. You can tune in here:

After nearly 13 hours of debate, the House Armed Services Committee approved a $695.9 billion military funding bill to make key reforms and repairs to our nation’s military and provide for our warfighters, including $417 million for JSTARS recapitalization. I'm also proud to report that five bipartisan amendments I introduced were included in the mark. Those amendments focus on recapitalization of the JSTARS fleet, training and recruitment of combat pilots and cyber security and defense personnel, and streamlining small arms acquisitions. You can read more here:
Home of the free, because of the brave! Happy 4th of July from our family to yours!
Our thoughts and prayers continue to remain with our friend and colleague Steve Scalise and his family during this time.

Just a few short weeks ago, I had the opportunity to visit East Asia to hear from our allies and U.S. military leaders in the region on the ever-increasing threats of the Kim Jong-un regime and the partnerships and resources we’re using to tackle those threats head-on. I recently sat down with Voice of America to talk about the trip, U.S.-China relations, and the North Korean nuclear threat. You can read more and watch my interview here:

If you’ve phoned or visited my Washington, D.C. office lately, you’ve probably spoken with Austin Griffin of Sylvester, a West Point Cadet who’s been interning in my office for the last several weeks. I had the honor of nominating Cadet Griffin to the United States Military Academy in West Point, New York, and it has been a pleasure having him in our D.C. office helping our legislative staff, giving constituent tours, attending briefings, and speaking with constituents.  We wish Cadet Griffin the best as he finishes his last year at West Point, and we thank him for his service to our great nation.

Yesterday, the Flying Tigers welcomed Col. Jennifer Short as she took command of the 23rd Wing at Moody Air Force Base. It was a great ceremony welcoming her to Moody and a fond farewell for Col. Thomas E. Kunkel, who leaves Moody to serve as Chief, Air Force Liaison, House of Representatives in Washington D.C.

Last night I spoke on the House Floor in opposition to an amendment to the Fiscal Year 2018 National Defense Authorization Act (FY18 NDAA) that would allow for conducting an additional round of Base Realignment and Closure (BRAC). Earlier this year, Secretary Mattis testified to the Armed Services Committee on the need to reassess our military’s current infrastructure resources and needs before closing or realigning current resources. If the Secretary of Defense needs to reassess our current capacity, then there is a need to halt BRAC to give time to do so.
Providing for Our National Defense in House Passage of NDAA

Tracy Ingram, a Georgia Science Ambassador and a second grade teacher at Len Lastinger Primary in Tifton, stopped by my D.C. office yesterday. Mrs. Ingram is in D.C. this week participating in the Summer Teacher Institutes at the Library of Congress. During the five-day program, she'll work with Library education specialists and subject-matter experts to learn effective practices for using primary sources in the classroom. I congratulate her on being selected to this program, and I look forward to hearing what innovative ideas she brings back to our classrooms.

Last night, I joined some of my colleagues on the House Floor in strong support of our community pharmacies. In many counties in Georgia’s Eighth District, locally owned and operated pharmacies are often the first stop when illness strikes, and ensuring their ability to remain competitive means stronger and healthier communities across the country. You can watch my remarks here:

A few months ago I, along with Members of the House and Senate Armed Services Committees, had the opportunity to visit the Hỏa Lò Prison (also known as the Hanoi Hilton) in Vietnam with Sen. John McCain. It was powerful to be there with him to hear his personal stories from his time held at the prison as a POW. Our thoughts and prayers are with Sen. McCain and his family during this time, and we stand with him and his loved ones as he fights this disease.

We had a new group of interns start in our Washington, D.C. office this week, and on Tuesday I was able to take them on a tour of the Dome of the U.S. Capitol Building. If you call or visit our D.C. office, please be sure to thank them for the important work they do!  (From left to right: Jim Henderson of Macon, Sean Grossnickle of Macon, Griffin Bell of Thomasville, and Brittany Sherrod of Swainsboro)

On Wednesday, I continued my push to provide rural America with reliable access to broadband. For me, all options are on the table when it comes to providing our rural communities with the technological resources they need to grow and thrive.   I look forward to continuing to work with my colleagues and the Trump Administration to bring 21st century technology to rural America with accountability measures in place for reliable and affordable service.

This morning, the House Agriculture Committee held a hearing on renegotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). One of the biggest concerns I have while we renegotiate the NAFTA is the adjustment of existing frameworks to improve our nation’s trade, in particular when it comes to achieving greater opportunities for poultry in Canada and specialty crops in Mexico without disrupting our current market access. I appreciate the conversations today and look forward to working with my colleagues to craft an agreement that will work on behalf of our nation’s producers and not against them.

Yesterday, the House passed legislation green-lighting funding to secure our border and fulfilling our promise to tackle the security concerns along our Southern border. Border security remains a top priority this Congress, and I’m proud to stand with my colleagues providing solutions to one of our nation’s biggest concerns.

Very honored to receive an award from the National Association of Community Health Centers. Community health centers are vital in our rural counties in Georgia and play a key role in keeping our communities healthy. Rest assured I am committed to continuing to advance policies that help, not hinder, these cornerstones in our communities.

Earlier this week, I had the opportunity to visit Georgia Veterans Education Career Transition Resource Center (VECTR) in Warner Robins. VECTR provides education and career resources for veterans and their families looking to transition to a Georgia public college, university, or the state’s workforce. It was a great visit, and I thank them for the important work they do for our veterans and their families.

Thank you to 23d Wing Commander - Col Jennifer Short and her team for showing me and a few members of my staff around Moody Air Force Base yesterday and highlighting Moody's unique and strategic missions. We appreciate it!
Today is the last day for our second session of summer interns. We thank them for their service to the people of Georgia's Eighth District and wish them the best.

I look forward to the Georgia Chamber of Commerce Congressional Luncheon each year. It's a time to come together to celebrate the things our businesses and state accomplish together to make Georgia one of the best places to live and do business. This year's event was particularly impactful as Members of the Georgia Congressional Delegation, state and local officials, and business leaders from across the state took time to pray for those impacted by the recent violence in Charlottesville, Virginia while condemning the violence and rhetoric we saw over the weekend. America is the greatest nation in the world, and the events of this past weekend have no place in our society.
America is the greatest country in the world, and there is no room for hate and violence like we saw over the weekend in Charlottesville.

Our thoughts and prayers are with those impacted by the horrific terror attack in Barcelona, Spain yesterday, including with the family and friends of the American citizen killed in the attack. The United States remains strongly committed to fighting against the threat of global terrorism and those forces which seek to erode and destroy democracy.

I commend President Trump’s three prong diplomatic, economic, and military strategy for U.S. involvement in Afghanistan outlined in last night’s remarks. The Administration’s new approach with regards to Afghanistan clearly focuses on achieving security for America, stability in Afghanistan, and a continued effort to root out terrorism around the world.

Our young people are certainly the future of our state, and supporting them and recognizing their successes are key to keeping our communities strong and thriving. On Tuesday, I met with Amelia Day, a member of the 4-H Club in Houston County. Amelia was selected as the national winner for the 2017 4-H Youth In Action Award for Citizenship for her leadership as founder of Operation: Veteran Smiles (OVS), a community service initiative she started at age 13. She’s a bright young woman, and I look forward to seeing her continued growth and success.
Our thoughts and prayers remain with those impacted by Hurricane Harvey and those aiding in rescue and relief efforts.

I just wrapped up an eight-day, four nation visit to East Africa, where I led a bipartisan Congressional Delegation of my colleagues on the House Armed Services Committee to visit joint U.S. training sites and military installations in Kenya, Djibouti, Sudan, and Somalia. The chief aim of the visit was to observe U.S. forces conducting security cooperation activities with local partners and see first-hand the challenges our warfighters face in combating the threat of terrorism in the region and around the world.

September is National Preparedness Month, and with impacts of Hurricane Harvey, our storms this past January, and the threat of Irma in the Atlantic, it’s a good time to make sure you and your family have a plan if and when a natural disaster strikes. The FEMA website is a good place to start:

For their sacrifices and commitment to our country, it is our duty to take care of our warfighters suffering from both the physical and invisible wounds of war. If you or someone you know is struggling, please seek help. The Air Force Suicide Prevention website and the VA are two good places to start in finding resources to help. #SuicidePreventionMonth
Very pleased my amendment aimed at supporting our strategic partners in Central and South America in counter-drug operations passed the House tonight.

Atkinson County is now listed under the State of Emergency for Hurricane Irma. Please stay vigilant as severe weather rolls in, and I urge those in the path of the storm to take proper precautions. #GA08
Are you prepared for a natural disaster?

President Trump just ordered federal assistance to supplement state and local response efforts in disaster declared counties in Georgia. Currently, the state of emergency includes: Appling, Atkinson, Bacon, Burke, Candler, Clinch, Coffee, Echols, Emanuel, Jenkins, Jeff Davis, Pierce, Screven, Tattnall, Toombs, Treutlen, Ware, Bulloch, Effingham, Evans, Bryan, Chatham, Liberty, Long, McIntosh, Waybe, Brantley, Camden, Charleton, and Glynn Counties. Additional counties could be added in the coming days.
Additional counties added under Governor Deal's state of emergency declaration.

Several Emergency Management Agencies across South GA are issuing voluntary evacuations ahead of Hurricane Irma, including in Coffee, Colquitt, Dougherty, Lee, Mitchell, Thomas, and Worth Counties. More information on voluntary evacuations, shelters, and curfews here:
Today we remember those who lost their lives in the 9/11 terror attacks and honor the brave first responders who acted. #NeverForget

As we begin cleaning up from the storm, our thoughts and prayers are with those impacted by Hurricane Irma, especially with the families and friends of those who lost their lives in Worth County, as well as all across the Southeast.

On Saturday, I’ll be hosting the Eighth District’s annual Military Service Academy Day. Representatives from the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, U.S. Naval Academy at Annapolis, the U.S. Air Force Academy, U.S. Coast Guard Academy, and the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy will be able to explain the nomination process to potential applicants and the requirements for applying to each academy.   Military Academy Day is free and open to the public. All high school students and their parents are welcome to attend. Students who are unable to attend can contact my office for more information on the application process or visit https://austinscott.house.gov/services/military-academy-nominations.
Today we celebrate the 70th #AirForceBirthday and seven decades of superior air power. Happy Birthday to the U.S. Air Force! Fly, Fight, Win!

We had a great turn out on Saturday at our annual Military Service Academy Day. Service Academy Day serves as a chance for high school students and parents to hear more about the process for applying to one of our nation’s military service academies.    If you know someone who couldn’t make it on Saturday, the can contact my office for more information on the application process or visit https://austinscott.house.gov/services/military-academy-nominations.

Thank you to Cook County Farm Bureau for hosting farmers yesterday morning in South GA to hear from USDA staff about potential assistance programs following Hurricane Irma.   If you were impacted by Hurricane Irma, please reach out to your local USDA office or my office for any questions you may have. You can also use the phone numbers listed here:

Earlier this week during the Air Space Cyber Conference, the JSTARS Crew from Robins AFB was recognized as Airborne Battle Management Crew of the Year for 2016. This is a big achievement, and I wish them congratulations on behalf of the Eighth District!

Yesterday, Sen. Johnny Isakson and I held a roundtable discussion in Tifton on the important role Georgia plays in combating global hunger. Joining us were representatives from the Malawi Ministry of Agriculture, CARE International, U.S. Global Leadership Coalition, U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), USDA Agricultural Research Service, Georgia Department of Agriculture, UGA School of Agriculture, American Peanut Council, and MANA Nutrition, among others.   I also stopped by MANA Nutrition's manufacturing facility in Fitzgerald yesterday. MANA is a ready-to-use therapeutic food (RUTF) made of fortified peanut paste formulated to meet nutrition needs, and their products are distributed to children in thirty-five countries around the world. Here are a couple pictures from yesterday:

ABAC plays an important role in educating our state’s future leaders while also boosting economic development in our communities. I congratulate ABAC on their growth, and I look forward to seeing their continued impact on our students and South Georgia.

Today the House welcomed back Representative Steve Scalise for the first time since the shooting at a congressional baseball game pratice back in June. Steve's words today were encouraging, and his wife Jennifer and his children Madison and Harrison remain in our thoughts and prayers as Steve continues his road to recovery, as well as with Officers David Bailey and Crystal Griner who were injured in the line of duty protecting Steve and others on the field that day.
Our condolences and prayers are with the victims, friends, and family of those killed and injured by this horrific attack in Las Vegas.

At twenty weeks, babies can hear music, respond to human voices, and even feel pain. I'm a proud cosponsor of H.R. 36, and I'm proud to report the House just passed the measure which prohibits abortions on unborn babies 20 weeks or older. #TheyFeelPain
If you haven't done so lately, today's a good day to thank a farmer for all their hard work in keeping our country and the world fed. To those who work in acres, not hours, we thank you!

Yesterday, a federal court ruled that Congress can continue to open each session with a prayer, which has been customary in our country for over two hundred years. I applaud the court for upholding this sacred and time honored tradition, and I look forward to Congress continuing to start each day by praying over the work we do for the American people.

REMINDER: The deadline to apply for a congressional nomination from my office for the US Military Service Academies is Friday, October 20, 2017.  Each year, I have the honor of nominating candidates for appointment to four of the five U.S. Service Academies: West Point - The U.S. Military Academy, the United States Naval Academy, the US Air Force Academy (Official), and the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy. The fifth service academy, the U.S. Coast Guard Academy, does not require a congressional nomination for appointment.  For more information on the U.S. Military Service Academy application process, please visit my website: https://austinscott.house.gov/services/military-academy-nominations

‪We had a great crowd at our Valdosta Senior Resource Fair this morning. My office is hosting a few more senior events this fall. You can find more information at https://austinscott.house.gov/seniors  If you can't make these events, you can schedule an individual appointment with my Warner Robins or Tifton District Offices throughout the months of October, November, and December. You can reach Tifton at 229-396-5175 and Warner Robins at 478-971-1776.

Each year I look forward to visiting the Sunbelt Ag Expo, as it serves as an important time to meet with constituents while learning more about advances in farm technology and innovation.    This year I had the opportunity to host a Farm Bill Listening Session on the opening day of the Expo. My colleagues U.S. Representatives Rick Allen of Georgia and Al Lawson of Florida joined me in hearing concerns from producers, local officials, and ag students on issues that impact them and ways they hope to see policies change in the 2018 Farm Bill.   It was a great event, and I look forward to attending again next year.

In case you haven't heard, my office is hosting a series of Senior Resource Fairs and Medicare Part D Workshops. Members of my staff and representatives from multiple federal agencies will be available to answer any questions and help you with different resources ranging from Medicare to Social Security to community programs.  We have events in Tifton, Gray, and Hawkinsville coming up. You can find a full list of events in your area on my website at https://austinscott.house.gov/seniors

Yesterday, I participated in the "Pass the Gavel," the first meeting marking the opening of final deliberations of the 2018 defense bill. Over the coming weeks, the House-Senate Conference Committee will work through differences of the House and Senate versions of the 2018 National Defense Authorization Act to hammer out a final bill that provides for our men and women in uniform. I'm very honored to be chosen an NDAA conferee this year and am glad we're underway continuing our important duty of providing for the common defense.
I took to the House Floor yesterday to recognize the 40th Anniversary of the Sunbelt Ag Expo and its contribution to farming and to South Georgia. You can watch here:

It was great to join President Trump today at the White House for his announcement declaring the opioid crisis a public health emergency. This declaration opens up more tools and resources to help the millions of Americans struggling with opioid use and drug addiction.

Our students are the future of our great state, and that is especially true when it comes to our students passionate about agriculture. Programs like National FFA Organization are critical to maintaining a strong, productive ag industry that feeds not only America, but the world.   I wish all our students attending the 90th FFA Convention and Expo a wonderful time, and I look forward to seeing where our nation’s youth ag programs take you! #IcanWeWillFFA

Tomorrow is National Prescription Take Back Day, a time when you can safely dispose of old or unwanted prescription drugs. For more information on the program or to find a collection site near you, click here: https://takebackday.dea.gov/.
Great conversation this afternoon with students and teachers from the government classes at Worth County High School. Thanks for having me!

Thanks to hardworking Georgians, our bright students, Governor Deal, and leaders in communities across the state, Georgia has once again been named the #1 state to do business, for the fifth year in a row.
A couple good safety tips from Warner Robins Police Department if you're heading out to trick or treat tonight. Everyone have fun and stay safe, and Happy Halloween.
Tragic news out of Texas this Sunday afternoon. Our sympathies and prayers are with those hurting from this senseless act. ‬

Medicare open enrollment runs until December 7th, and my office is hosting a couple more of our Medicare Part D Workshops: Ashburn on 11/16 and Thomasville on 11/28.   You can find more information on these events and how to schedule an individual meeting with a member of my staff by clicking here: https://austinscott.house.gov/seniors
Wishing the men and women of the United States Marine Corps a Happy 242nd Birthday. #SemperFi

Mexico’s unfair trade practices have become unsustainable for Georgia’s fresh fruit and vegetable sector, and it is vital that as we renegotiate NAFTA we consider using more near-term remedial tools to help correct these practices.
To our veterans and their families: Thank you for your service, sacrifice, and bravery. Happy Veterans Day.
The House just passed the Fiscal Year 2018 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) by a vote of 356-70, providing critical resources for our nation's warfighters and their families. Read more here:

Our Ashburn Medicare Part D Workshop is TOMORROW at 9:00 a.m. at the Turner County Civic Center. You can call our Tifton office (229-396-5175) for more information or to scheduled an individual meeting with a member of my staff if you cannot make this event. Our last Medicare Part D Workshop of the year will be in Thomasville on 11/28.
Farmers in 83 counties in Georgia can now apply for help from the USDA for damages related to Hurricane Irma.
The House just passed the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act.
Are you signed up for my e-newsletter? Don't miss the latest news and information from my office. You can sign up here: https://austinscott.house.gov/contact/newsletter
Today is Small Business Saturday, a time to support our local small business who contribute so much to our communities.
Happy Thanksgiving from our family to yours.

Our Thomasville Medicare Part D Workshop is TOMORROW at 10:00 a.m. at the Thomas County Public Library. You can call our Tifton office (229-396-5175) for more information or to schedule an individual meeting with a member of my staff if you cannot make this event.

This morning, Speaker Paul Ryan signed the Fiscal Year 2018 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) to provide for our nation’s military and give our troops the largest pay raise in eight years. Next stop: The White House to become law. I’m very proud of this bill, and I look forward to seeing the Eighth District’s critical missions and the men and women who support them thrive under this piece of legislation.
Reforms to TRICARE benefits are coming January 1, 2018, and more than 9.4 million beneficiaries worldwide will be affected. You can find more information on what plans are changing and more here:
Christmas came early for the Scott family this year! We are proud to introduce John Philip Scott! 8.5 lbs, 20.5 inches.

I applaud President Trump's historic decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israel’s capital and relocate our embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, continuing the United States commitment to the Jewish people.

Today, on the 76th Anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor, we honor those who lost their lives and the Greatest Generation who fought to defend our great nation. In May, I had the opportunity to pay my respects at the USS Arizona Memorial in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii. It was a humbling moment and a solemn reminder of those who’ve given the ultimate sacrifice for our freedoms.
Especially thankful this birthday. Vivien, Wells, Gabriela, John Philip and I thank you for all the kind wishes.

Today, President Trump signed the Fiscal Year 2018 National Defense Authorization Act, which will fund our nation’s military, address our readiness crisis, confront our nation’s enemies across the world, address the North Korean threat, rebuild our military, protect force structure, and provide for our military families.

Thankful for the opportunity to write a few Christmas cards to our troops stationed in Djibouti who will not be with their loved ones this Christmas. To all our deployed servicemen and women and their families: We are thinking of you during the holidays, and Merry Christmas.

One third of the A-10C aircraft fleet is in desperate need of wing set replacements in order to safely continue their important missions, and as the only plane in the U.S. military specifically designed for Close Air Support and Combat Search and Rescue it is crucial the fleet undergo wing replacement to continue their missions fighting ISIS and providing ground support to troops around the world.

The Farm Bill is critical to our nation's agriculture industry and rural America. I echo Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue: Each commodity is vastly different, and we must strike a balance for our various producers.

The House just passed a historical, sweeping reform of our nation’s tax code. For families across Georgia, today’s legislation means more jobs, more take-home pay, and more money in their own pockets. While I am very happy with the first major overhaul of our tax code in over thirty years, there is still a lot of work to be done getting our economy back on track, and I look forward to continuing to work with the Trump Administration and my colleagues in Congress to expand our economy, grow wages, and ease burdensome federal regulations.
Great meeting with Vice President Mike Pence before yesterday’s tax reform vote. We promised to bring meaningful tax reform to the American people by Christmas, and we have delivered!
Wishing former Georgia Governor, U.S. Department of Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue a very happy birthday.
NA
Merry Christmas from our family to yours.
REMINDER: Reforms to #TRICARE benefits are coming Jan. 1 & more than 9.4M beneficiaries worldwide will be affected. You can find information on what plans are changing and more here:
